content: The Act is titled the "National Electricity and Environmental Technology Research and Development Act." Congress finds that reliable, affordable, increasingly clean electricity is crucial for powering the growing US economy. The increasing use of electrotechnologies, environmental concerns, a competitive electricity market, and rising energy prices highlight the importance of clean electricity. Coal, currently generating over half of US electricity, is the most abundant fossil energy resource in the country. Coal, accounting for over half of US electricity generation, is the most abundant fossil energy resource in the country, with enough supply to last 250 years at current usage rates. SEC. 7 authorizes $100,000,000 annually from 2002 to 2012 for sections 4, 5, and 6. This funding is separate from existing authorizations and does not cap Department of Energy fossil energy research. The Act requires coal-based electric generation units with at least 50 megawatts to achieve efficiency improvements or enhance environmental performance related to sulfur dioxide control. The Act mandates efficiency improvements or environmental enhancements for coal-based electric generation units with at least 50 megawatts, including significant improvements in environmental performance related to sulfur dioxide control, nitrogen oxide, or mercury. It also encourages recycling or reusing a significant portion of coal combustion or gasification wastes. The Act requires coal-based electric generation units to make efficiency improvements and environmental enhancements, including capturing and reusing carbon dioxide at a lower cost than current technologies. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. The Secretary must solicit proposals for projects at new or existing facilities to achieve specified performance levels within 180 days of transmitting the plan to Congress. Proposals may include projects demonstrating a 3 percentage point efficiency improvement compared to the unit's efficiency at the time of the Act's enactment. A solicitation may include a proposal for a project demonstrating an overall design efficiency improvement of at least 3 percentage points without increasing emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxide, particulate matter, mercury, or carbon monoxide.
